Terminology
Terminology

• Pharmacokinetics (PK): time course of • P h a r m a c o k i n e t i c s
( P K ) :
t i m e
c o u r s e
o f

drug concentrations in the plasma (sometimes in other fluids and tissues) resulting from a particular dosing regimen. • Pharmacodynamics (PD): relationship between drug concentrations in plasma (or other fluids and tissues) and a resulting pharmacological effect.
drug concentrations in the plasma
(sometimes in other fluids and tissues)
resulting from a particular dosing regimen.

r e l a t i o n s h i p
between drug concentrations in plasma (or
other fluids and tissues) and a resulting
pharmacological effect.

Bioequivalence
Bioequivalence

• 21 CFR 320.1 (e) • the lack of a difference in the rate and extent to which the active ingredient or active moiety in pharmaceutical equivalents or pharmaceutical alternatives becomes available at the site of drug action when administered at the same molar dose under similar conditions in an appropriately designed study.
• 21 CFR 320.1 (e)
• the lack of a difference in the rate and extent
to which the active ingredient or active moiety
in pharmaceutical equivalents or
pharmaceutical alternatives becomes
available at the site of drug action when
administered at the same molar dose under
similar conditions in an appropriately
designed study.

Determining Bioequivalence
Determining Bioequivalence

• Formulations: – Reference – Test
• Formulations:
– Reference
– Test

• Study design (typical): – healthy volunteers – single dose, two-way crossover – administer drug under fasted conditions
• Study design (typical):
– healthy volunteers
– single dose, two-way crossover
– administer drug under fasted conditions

Determining Bioequivalence
Determining Bioequivalence

• Compare Test vs. Reference – Ratios for AUC and Cmax – Determine 90% confidence interval for ratios – Criteria for log-transformed data: • 90% CI: 0.8 to 1.25 (80% to 125%)
• Compare Test vs. Reference
– Ratios for AUC and Cmax
– Determine 90% confidence interval for ratios
– Criteria for log-transformed data:
• 90% CI: 0.8 to 1.25 (80% to 125%)

Bioequivalence
Bioequivalence

Bioequivalence: Assumptions
Bioequivalence:
Assumptions

• Plasma concentration data- surrogate
• Plasma concentration data- surrogate

for active site
for active site

• Rate and extent of absorption are similar- no significant difference in exposure to drug
• Rate and extent of absorption are
similar- no significant difference in
exposure to drug

• Can extrapolate safety and efficacy data from reference product to test product
• Can extrapolate safety and efficacy data
from reference product to test product

Bioequivalence
Bioequivalence

• Flexibility of BE criteria
• Flexibility of BE criteria

– No flexibility for approval of generic drugs – Innovator drugs- There is some room for flexibility. Safety and efficacy data or exposure-response data may make it possible to determine that differences are not meaningful.
– No flexibility for approval of generic drugs
– Innovator drugs- There is some room for
flexibility. Safety and efficacy data or
exposure-response data may make it
possible to determine that differences are
not meaningful.

New Formulations

New Formulations
New Formulations

• Modified release formulations or prodrugs
• Modified release formulations or prodrugs

New Formulations
New Formulations

21 CFR 320.23 (b) ... Some pharmaceutical equivalents or pharmaceutical alternatives may be equivalent in the extent of their absorption but not in their rate of absorption and yet may be considered bioequivalent because such differences in the rate of absorption are intentional and are reflected in the labeling, are not essential to the attainment of effective body concentrations on chronic use, and are considered medically insignificant for the particular drug product studied.

Example of efficacy data • Indinavir 800 mg q8hr vs. 1200 mg q12hr • 24 weeks:
Example of efficacy data
• Indinavir 800 mg q8hr vs. 1200 mg q12hr
• 24 weeks:

The 1200 mg q12hr regimen was less efficacious than the 800 mg q8hr regimen.
The 1200 mg q12hr regimen was less
efficacious than the 800 mg q8hr regimen.

and dosing regimen.

• Formulation change may allow a

change in dosing regimen, with little change in AUC, Cmax or Cmin.
change in dosing regimen, with little
change in AUC, Cmax or Cmin.

and Cmin, need to consider shape of
the concentration vs. time curve.

Human Drug and Biologic Products

approval, when BE or “comparable
concentrations” have not been

between blood concentrations and

response.

Drug Interactions
Drug Interactions

• Coadministration of two or more drugs results in a change in exposure and the potential need for a dose adjustment
• Coadministration of two or more drugs
results in a change in exposure and the
potential need for a dose adjustment

• PK enhancer: intentional use of subtherapeutic dose one drug to increase concentrations of another drug
• PK enhancer: intentional use of
subtherapeutic dose one drug to
increase concentrations of another drug

Pediatric Dosing
Pediatric Dosing

• There are many factors to consider when evaluating new formulations, alternative dosing regimens and drug interaction results for antiretroviral drugs.
• There are many factors to consider
when evaluating new formulations,
alternative dosing regimens and drug
interaction results for antiretroviral
drugs.

• Considering these factors in the context
• Considering these factors in the context

of dosing pediatric patients adds another layer of complexity.
of dosing pediatric patients adds
another layer of complexity.

Pediatric Dosing
Pediatric Dosing

• 21 CFR 201.57(f)(9)(iv) • Allows inclusion of pediatric use
• 21 CFR 201.57(f)(9)(iv)
• Allows inclusion of pediatric use

information in the label without controlled clinical trials of the use in children.
information in the label without controlled
clinical trials of the use in children.

• Course of disease should be similar in
• Course of disease should be similar in

pediatric and adult populations.
pediatric and adult populations.

• Sponsor must provide other information
• Sponsor must provide other information

to support use in children.
to support use in children.

Pediatric Dosing
Pediatric Dosing

• Additional information- PK data for drug in
• Additional information- PK data for drug in

pediatric population, to allow dose selection
pediatric population, to allow dose
selection

• Evidence of comparable concentrations
• Evidence of comparable concentrations

between children and adults, or exposure- response data, can link efficacy data. • Some additional safety data may be
between children and adults, or exposure-
response data, can link efficacy data.
• Some additional safety data may be

requested.
requested.

Using PK/PD
Using PK/PD

• Goals:
• Goals:
